leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 1.11] r 1.11 Reckoning of time (cf SCR Part 2, rule 2; DCR Part 3, rule 1; LCR Part 4, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Reckoning of time (cf SCR Part 2, rule 2; DCR Part 3, rule 1; LCR Part 4, rule 1)

p.text: Any period of time fixed by these rules, or by any judgment or order of the court or by any document in any proceedings, is to be reckoned in accordance with this rule.
If a time of one day or longer is to be reckoned by reference to a given day or event, the given day or the day of the given event is not to be counted.
If, apart from this subrule, the period in question, being a period of 5 days or less, would include a day or part of a day on which the registry is closed, that day is to be excluded.
If the last day for doing a thing is, or a thing is to be done on, a day on which the registry is closed, the thing may be done on the next day on which the registry is open.
Section 36 of the Interpretation Act 1987 (which relates to the reckoning of time) does not apply to these rules.

level.toc-caption: [1.11.5] Parts of days and days when the registry is closed

p.text: Legislation cited in [1.11.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 1.11(2), Rule 1.11(3), Rule 1.11(4), r 14.3, r 18.4.

heading.title: Parts of days and days when the registry is closed

p.text: Rule 1.11(2) embraces the general principle that when time is to be calculated to or from a given date, that date is not included in the calculation: see for example, Chitty on Contracts: General Principles, 27th ed, Sweet and Maxwell Ltd, 1994, para [21–020]. The rule can produce apparently different results in calculating time, depending upon whether the task is to determine the period within which something must be done or, alternatively, a period of notice that must elapse before something may be done. In the former case, the postulated event (eg, filing a defence) must occur before midnight (more usually close of business) on the last day of the period. In the latter case, the postulated event may not occur until all the days of notice have ended: Howey & Co Pty Ltd v Creative Products International Pty Ltd [1973] 2 NSWLR 898 (service must be effected on Thursday of the prior week in order to give five days notice of a Friday application); R v Long [1960] 1 QB 681; [1959] 3 All ER 559 (three days notice); Re Hector Whaling Ltd [1936] Ch 208; (1936) 52 TLR 142 (21 days notice); contrast Schnabel v Allard [1967] 1 QB 627 (landlord and tenant — not less than four weeks notice). Rule 1.11(3) has the effect of extending time when periods of five days or less would include days when the court registry is closed. (A day when the office may be opened by paying an extra fee is to be considered as a day on which the registry is closed: Scott v Larkin (1830) 7 Bing 109.) Rule 1.11(4) provides for a further “extension” where a time for compliance would otherwise expire on a day when the court registry is closed. The consequence of these provisions is that while weekends are not included in the three-day notice period, r 18.4 requires service of notices of motion; they are taken into account in calculating the normal 28-day period for filing a defence provided for under r 14.3 . However, if the period expires on a weekend or public holiday, it can be filed at any time on the next day the registry is open: Gwyn v Anthony (1882) Tarl 123. Because the two provisions of the rules operate by reference to slightly different criteria, they produce the apparently anomalous result that “five days’ notice” may actually result in a party having the benefit of seven calendar days notice (ie, more notice than would apply if a “six-day notice” expired on a weekday). This can occur because a five-day notice period must span Saturday and Sunday, and neither is to be counted as part of the period for the purpose of the Rules: Howey & Co Pty Ltd v Creative Products International Pty Ltd [1973] 2 NSWLR 898 .
Legislation cited in [1.11.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 1.11(5).
(NSW) Interpretation Act 1987 s 36.

This rule does not apply where the times have been fixed by statute: Stitt v Richards (1897) 18 LR (NSW) (Eq) 1; 13 WN (NSW) 145. However, and notwithstanding r 1.11(5) , s 36 of the Interpretation Act 1987 will apply to extend such times in the appropriate case (Thompson v Les Harrison Contracting Co [1976] VR 238 ), and will, because it is to substantially the same effect as the present rule, usually produce a similar result.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 1.12] r 1.12 Extension and abridgment of time (cf SCR Part 2, rule 3; DCR Part 3, rule 2; LCR Part 4, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Extension and abridgment of time (cf SCR Part 2, rule 3; DCR Part 3, rule 2; LCR Part 4, rule 2)

p.text: Subject to these rules, the court may, by order, extend or abridge any time fixed by these rules or by any judgment or order of the court.
[ subr (1) am Gaz 116 of 7 September 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[1], effective 7 September 2007]
The court may extend time under this rule, either before or after the time expires, and may do so after the time expires even if an application for extension is made after the time expires.

level.toc-caption: [1.12.5] Consent orders — alteration of times fixed by

heading.title: Consent orders — alteration of times fixed by

p.text: The court’s jurisdiction under this rule cannot be excluded by agreement of the parties. However, the terms of an agreement embodied in a consent order may be relevant to the exercise of that jurisdiction: Morgan v 45 Flers Avenue Pty Ltd (1987) 11 NSWLR 573 at 579, 580 . Indeed, time limits fixed by consent will rarely be enlarged, except by consent: Australasian Automatic Weighing Machine Co v Walter [1891] WN 170; Gamble v Killingsworth & McLean Publishing Co Pty Ltd [1970] VR 161 . Generally, an exceptional case would be required before the court would set aside or vary times fixed by a consent order based on a free and voluntary contract, where the underlying agreement could not be set aside or varied: Paino v Hofbauer (1988) 13 NSWLR 193 at 198 (agreed instalment payment schedule — extension overruled on appeal); see also Deputy Cmr of Taxation v Zarzycki (1990) 96 ALR 146; 21 ATR 575; BC9000746 ; H & G Group Pty Ltd v Pilot Developments Pty Ltd [2002] NSWSC 257; BC200201510 (time extended where non-compliance contributed to by opposing party’s breach of undertaking).

level.toc-caption: [1.12.10] Costs relating to extension or abridgement

p.text: Legislation cited in [1.12.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 42.4(2)(c).

heading.title: Costs relating to extension or abridgement

p.text: A party who applies for an extension of time will generally be ordered to pay the costs of, and those occasioned by, the application, unless the court otherwise orders. Even where that party ultimately succeeds in the proceedings, they will not ordinarily be entitled to recover their own costs of the application or to recover costs they have been ordered to pay another party relating to the extension of time: see r 42.4(2)(c) .

level.toc-caption: [1.12.15] Cross-claim — extension of time to permit

heading.title: Cross-claim — extension of time to permit

p.text: Time may be extended under this rule to allow a cross-claim to be filed after the principal proceedings have been discontinued: Carlton International plc v Crayford Freight Services Ltd (1998) 82 FCR 328; 162 ALR 119; BC9800909 . Similarly, the court may extend the time for filing a cross-claim even though judgment has been given on the plaintiff’s claim: Seltsam Pty Ltd v Energy Australia; Re Banham (1999) 17 NSWCCR 720; [1999] NSWCA 89; BC9901424 . See also [9.1.50] and [9.10.5] .

level.toc-caption: [1.12.20] Endorsement of process where time abridged

heading.title: Endorsement of process where time abridged

p.text: Where the time for service has been shortened, the originating process must bear an appropriate note with particulars of the order abridging time. The endorsement should be to the effect that the document was “filed pursuant to leave granted by, for example, Justice X, 17 July 2005.” A similar endorsement should appear whenever the court gives leave to file an amended originating process.

level.toc-caption: [1.12.25] Extension and abridgment — general and remedial discretion

p.text: Legislation cited in [1.12.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 1.12.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ss 14–16, ss 56–59, s 58, 61–63.

heading.title: Extension and abridgment — general and remedial discretion

p.text: Rule 1.12 confers a general discretion which both complements, and is subject to the same principles as, the court's general power to give directions — including directions which dispense with the requirements of the Rules and correct procedural irregularities (see CPA ss 14–16 and ss 56–59 , 61–63 ). The discretion is clearly capable of a wide application. The general principle for its exercise, is that of determining the “justice of the case” in the particular circumstances: Arthur Andersen Corporate Finance Pty Ltd v Buzzle Operations Pty Ltd (in liq) [2009] NSWCA 104; BC200903847 at [28]–[34] (application for extension of time for service — tardy service after limitation period expired — deliberate delay — extension refused); Agricultural & Rural Finance Pty Ltd v Kirk (2011) 82 ACSR 390; [2011] NSWCA 67; BC201101402 at [94] and [222] (application granted — majority of defendants served — test case determination — subsequent extension relating to other defendants). The rule permits the extension of time whenever it is appropriate to do so to avoid injustice: FAI General Insurance Co Ltd v Southern Cross Exploration NL (1988) 165 CLR 268 at 283–4; 77 ALR 411; 62 ALJR 216; BC8802594 (extension after expiry of time for compliance with a self executing order dismissing proceedings); El Ali v Government Insurance Office of NSW (1988) 15 NSWLR 303 (extension after expiry of time to apply for arbitration rehearing); Schafer v Blyth [1920] 3 KB 140 at 143 (extension after expiry of time for application to set aside default judgment). The discretion can be exercised irrespective of whether the time limit is contained in the Rules or has been fixed by an order in particular proceedings: Paino v Hofbauer (1988) 13 NSWLR 193 at 196 .

Proper exercise of the discretion will ordinarily justify an extension of any procedural time limit, if the extension is genuinely sought for a proper purpose, the extension will cause no significant substantive prejudice to the other parties, and appropriate orders for costs, or the imposition of other terms, otherwise adequately protect them from any disadvantage caused by the extension: see [1.12.27] ; Adams v Kennick Trading (Int) Ltd (1986) 4 NSWLR 503; 10 ALN N47 ; Atwood v Chichester (1878) 3 QBD 722 at 723 ; Eaton v Storer (1882) 22 Ch D 91 at 92 ; Commissioner for Railways v Bielewicz [1963] NSWR 482 at 486; [1963] SR (NSW) 466 at 468 ; Percy v General-Motors Holden's Pty Ltd [1975] 1 NSWLR 289 at 295–6 (eg, an order extending time to file a requisition for trial by jury should normally be made — unless jury trial was inappropriate).

This general rule is justifiable by the dual propositions that procedural time limits are usually not ends in themselves and that the interests of justice normally require genuine issues be determined on their merits, where that can be done with fairness to all concerned, notwithstanding relevant delay: Outboard Marine Australia Pty Ltd v Byrnes [1974] 1 NSWLR 27 at 30 ; Garrard (t/as Arthur Anderson & Co) v Email Furniture Pty Ltd (1993) 32 NSWLR 662 at 669 (parties ought not attempt to gain a forensic advantage by rigidly enforcing time limits specified in the Rules). The general rule thus stated is consistent with the overriding purpose stated in CPA s 56 and the dictates of justice which CPA s 58 stipulates as a mandatory consideration.

heading.title: Requirement to establish proper grounds for extension of time:

p.text: Neither the present rule, nor those provisions of the CPA, provide an unqualified right to an extension of time: Ratnam v Cumarasamy [1964] 3 All ER 933; [1965] 1 WLR 8 ; Outboard Marine Australia Pty Ltd v Byrnes, above, at 30. An applicant must establish a sufficient reason for an extension of time being granted: Franklin House Ltd v ANI Corporation Ltd (Windeyer J, 2 November 1994, unreported); Kleinwort Benson Ltd v Barbrak [1987] AC 597 at 622–3; [1987] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 1 . The effect of granting or refusing the application, the nature and extent of the non-compliance, as well as delay in making an application for extension, are relevant to the exercise of the discretion to extend time: Schafer v Blyth, above. Absence of resultant material prejudice to an applicant may justify refusal of the application: Outboard Marine Australia Pty Ltd v Byrnes [1974] 1 NSWLR 27 (debtor’s 6 month delay in applying for leave to appeal — liability judgment already obtained against third party — application refused). Conversely, the likelihood that extension will cause material prejudice to third parties provides a reason to refuse an extension: El Ali v Government Insurance Office of NSW (1988) 15 NSWLR 303 . Depending on the nature of the non-compliance, and the consequences of refusal of an extension, satisfactory explanation of delay is not a pre-condition to the favorable exercise of the discretion: Comcare v A'Hearn (1993) 119 ALR 85; 45 FCR 441; 18 AAR 366 ; Chalk v Cmr for Superannuation (1994) 50 FCR 150 at 155–6; 33 ALD 420; 19 AAR 450; BC9405771 . But the presence or absence of a satisfactory explanation will be an influential factor where exercise of the discretion is likely either to cause material disadvantage to the opposing party, or deprive them of a benefit that has accrued as a result of the delay: Tolcher v Gordon (2005) 53 ACSR 442; 23 ACLC 798; [2005] NSWCA 135; BC200502708 at [5], [6], and [130] . Sufficient explanation may be provided by evidence that the relevant delay was principally attributable to circumstances beyond the applicant’s control: Tolcher v Gordon (2005) 53 ACSR 442; 23 ACLC 798; [2005] NSWCA 135; BC200502708 at [109]–[112] (difficulty in effecting service — solicitor’s default — successful application to set aside default dismissal); compare Pell v Hodges [2007] NSWCA 234; BC200707569 at [30] (application for extension of time for service — 19 months after the expiration of limitation period — apparently deliberate delay in effecting service — inadequate reasons for delay — application refused).

level.toc-caption: [1.12.27] Interests of justice and the merits of the party claiming an extension of time

p.text: Legislation cited in [1.12.27] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 61(3).

heading.title: Interests of justice and the merits of the party claiming an extension of time

p.text: The general principle favouring extension of time in order avoid injustice assumes that the conduct of the applicant does not otherwise involve gross default or delay that would attract exercise of the power conferred by CPA s 61(3) . It also assumes at least the arguable merits of the claim or defence propounded by the applicant. But where the application is for a mere extension of time, there is no gross delay, no non-compliance with the rules and no vested right of the opposing party (as a consequence of the expiry of time), consideration of the merits of the parties’ position may be made by an impressionistic assessment rather than involve a detailed evaluation: Jackamarra v Krakouer (1998) 195 CLR 516 at 521; 153 ALR 276; [1998] HCA 27; BC9801285 (application for extension of time to take a step in an appeal) (distinguishing Palata Investments Ltd v Burt & Sinfield Ltd [1985] 2 All ER 517; [1985] 1 WLR 942 (extension of time to appeal)).

level.toc-caption: [1.12.30] Extension and abridgment — limitations on exercise of the discretion

heading.title: Extension and abridgment — limitations on exercise of the discretion

p.text: The discretion conferred by this rule should not be exercised to undermine the general importance of compliance with prescribed court procedures: Keevers v O’Neill [1977] 1 NSWLR 587 at 591; (1977) 30 FLR 300 . Periods of notice contemplated by the rules should be abridged only for sufficient cause and should not be abridged or extended where doing so would confer an inappropriate forensic advantage: Ratnam v Cumarasamy [1964] 3 All ER 933 at 935; [1965] 1 WLR 8 . For example, the rules require that five clear days notice of a summons must be given to defendants. Three clear days notice must be given of an interlocutory application. These times are fixed to enable the opposing party to have sufficient time to answer the claim. The court will be reluctant to abridge time ex parte where: (i) the moving party has delayed, especially where the bulk or complexity of the supporting material indicates a degree of preparation that may place the other party at an unfair disadvantage if it is required to respond in a shortened time; or (ii) where the other parties are represented and have not been consulted as to a convenient return day.

level.toc-caption: [1.12.35] Legal representatives — extensions where delay attributable to

heading.title: Legal representatives — extensions where delay attributable to

p.text: The fact that the delay has been caused by the legal representatives, rather than the client personally, often affords a sound basis for an application to extend time. However, it will not always do so and litigants may be disadvantaged by inaction on the part of legal representatives, especially where they have abstained from inquiry as to the progress of the proceedings: Stollznow v Calvert [1980] 2 NSWLR 749 at 753 . See Allen v Sir Alfred McAlpine & Sons Ltd [1968] 2 QB 229 at 254, 258, 260–1; [1968] 1 All ER 543 ; O’Neill v Kaddatz [1964] NSWR 1280 (solicitor's mistake — extension of time granted); Sophron v Nominal Defendant (1957) 96 CLR 469; 31 ALJR 395; BC5700210 (refusal of extension despite solicitor's explanation); Gamble v Killingsworth & McLean Publishing Co Pty Ltd [1970] VR 161 at 176–7 ; Birkett v James [1978] AC 297; [1977] 2 All ER 801 . The fact that the applicant for extension has a potential claim against their solicitor is a relevant consideration in the exercise of the discretion, but one which will generally be accorded relatively little weight: Morrison v Judd (NSWCA, Kirby P, Meagher and Powell JJA, No 405041/95, 10 October 1995, unreported, BC9507158) referred to with approval in Groth v Audet (2006) 65 NSWLR 388; [2006] NSWCA 48; BC200602111 at [27] per Tobias JA with whom Mason P and Basten JA agreed; see also Morton v Jools (1992) Aust Torts Reports ¶81-164; BC9202047 ; McAndrew v Wyoming Nursing Home (NSWCA, Sperling J, 5 December 1997, unreported); Diaz v Truong (2002) 37 MVR 158; [2002] NSWCA 265; BC200204664 at [129] ; Blackburn v Allianz Australia Insurance Ltd [2004] NSWCA 385; BC200408096 .
Legislation cited in [1.12.40] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Legal Aid Commission Act 1979 s 57.

Delay often occurs because of, or is sought to be justified by, a pending application for legal aid. English authority is to the effect that this is not a sufficient justification for an extension of time: Baker v Bowketts Cakes Ltd [1966] 2 All ER 290 at 292; [1966] 1 WLR 861 at 865 . However, regard must be had to s 57 of the Legal Aid Commission Act 1979 which can, in certain circumstances, oblige the court to grant an adjournment where a bona fide appeal is pending against a refusal of an application for legal aid.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 1.13] r 1.13 Fixing times (cf SCR Part 2, rule 4; DCR Part 3, rule 3; LCR Part 4, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Fixing times (cf SCR Part 2, rule 4; DCR Part 3, rule 3; LCR Part 4, rule 3)

p.text: If no time is fixed by these rules, or by any judgment or order of the court, for the doing of any thing in or in connection with any proceedings, the court may, by order, fix the time within which the thing is to be done.
Legislation cited in [1.13.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 6.9.

Where proceedings have been commenced by statement of claim, a defendant must enter an appearance within 28 days of service or within seven days of the refusal of an application to set aside the state of claim. Where proceedings have been commenced by summons, the defendant must enter an appearance by the return day stated in the summons or within seven days of the refusal of any application to set aside the summons: r 6.9 .
Legislation cited in [1.13.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 14.3(1).

A defendant must file a defence within 28 days of the service of any statement of claim or cross-claim: r 14.3(1) . No defence is ordinarily filed to a summons, although a defence may be required either by a specific direction of the court or under Practice Notes applying to particular proceedings.
Legislation cited in [1.13.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 6.2.

Initiating process is valid for service for six months after filing in the Supreme Court or the Local Court. Initiating process filed in the District Court is valid to service for one month, unless one of the defendants is to be served outside New South Wales, in which case the initiating process is valid for six months: r 6.2 .
